Universal Screening

The “new norm” of today’s classrooms will likely present an overall increase in academic inconsistencies prevalent in students. This isn’t to say those inconsistencies did not exist previously. Still, today, the volume and frequency of inconsistencies predict a significant scaled increase in academic challenges for many students in many classrooms. With an opportunity for such widespread weaknesses, students needing additional support must be identified immediately. 

Universal screening identifies students in need before additional instructional time passes, and the issues manifest themselves through poor grades and problematic behavior. 

The Council of Chief School State Officers defines universal screening as “screening tests are periodically conducted, usually two or three times during a school year, to identify students who may be at risk, monitor student progress, or predict students’ likelihood of success on meeting or exceeding curricular benchmarks. Universal screening tests are typically brief and conducted with all students at a particular grade level.” 

It is important to note that universal screening assessments should be systematically developed and implemented building-wide to ensure the validity and reliability of results. Below are a few steps suggested by the National Center for Education Evaluation and Regional Assistance that can be taken to ensure a good universal screening process is developed.
